div.l: Of half a busshell floure wele y bake
Thus is this proude myln̉er wele y bete
And hath loste the gryndyng of the whete
And for the Souper eủery dele
Of aleyn and of Iohn that betyn hym wele
His wyf is swyved and his doughter so als
Lo swyche it is a myln̉er to be fals
And therto thus prouerbe is seide full sothe
Hym dare nought evyll wene that wele dothe
A giloure shall be giled be
And god that Sitteste in maieste
Saue all this companye grete and smale
And thus haue I quyt the myln̉er his tale
¶ Here endeth the reves tale of the mylnere and
Here begynneth the ꝓprologe of the coke
The Coke of london whiles the reve spake
For Ioye he thought he clawed hym on the bak
Ha ha quod he he hath saide for cristes passioıı̄un
This mylnere hath a sharpe conclusioıı̄un
Vppon his argument of his bourgage
Wele saide Salaman in his langage
Ne bryng nought eủery man to his house ·
For herbegage be nyght is peryllous
Wele aught aman avised for to be
Whome that he bryngeth to his pⁱrivete
I pray to god so yeve me care
If eủer sithen that I hight of hogge of hogge hogge of ware
Herde I neủer better a myln̉er sette awerke
He hadde a Iape of malyce in the derke
And therfore if ye vouche sauf to here
A tale of me that am a pore man
I wil you telle as wele as I can
A litell Iape that felle in oure cite
Oure hoste saide I graunte it the
Nowe telle on Rog̉er loke it be good
For many a pasty hast thou lette blode
And many a Iak of Doủere haste thou solde
That hath bene twys hote and twys colde
Of many a pilgryme haste thou hadde cristes cors
For thy persly they faren the worse
That they haue eten wᵗith the stoble gose
For in thy shoppe is many a flee louse
Nowe gentyll Rog̉er be thy name
